name: acetamide, 2-chloro-n-(2-methyl-2h-benzotriazol-
Reason: 2-chloro-N-(2-methyl-2H-benzotriazol-5-yl)acetamide is a compound with several functional groups that can influence its melting point. The basic unit we can compare to is acetamide, which has a melting point of 82 degrees Celsius. The additional functional groups and structural features in 2-chloro-N-(2-methyl-2H-benzotriazol-5-yl)acetamide will affect its melting point: (1) The 2-chloro group (Cl) is an electron-withdrawing group that introduces a significant dipole, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +10 degrees Celsius; (2) The 2-methyl-2H-benzotriazol-5-yl group is a bulky and rigid structure that can participate in dipole interactions and potentially hydrogen bonding, further raising the melting point by about +50 degrees Celsius; (3) The acetamide group (ClCC(=O)N) includes functionalities related to amides, which can significantly increase the melting point due to hydrogen bonding, adding about +30 degrees Celsius. Summing these modifications gives us an estimated melting point shift.
